description: From Middle English knave, knafe, from Old English cnafa (“child, boy, youth; servant”), from Proto-West Germanic *knabō.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A boy; especially, a boy servant.

examples: Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave that, doting on his own obsequious bondage, wears out his time, much like his master's ass, For naught but provender, and when he's old – cashier'd! Whip me such honest knaves.

entries.meaning: A tricky, deceitful fellow; a dishonest person.
(card games) A playing card marked with the figure of a servant or soldier; a jack.
